run.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to move very quickly, by moving your legs more quickly than when you walk
run.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: The children came running out of the house.
Women ran screaming, with children in their arms.
Jane struggled free and ran for her life (=ran in order to avoid being killed).
Hurry! Run for it (=run as quickly as possible in order to escape)!
He picked up the child and ran like hell (=ran very quickly, especially in order to escape).
I ran down the stairs as fast as I could.
He was running towards the door.
The boys ran off into the crowd.
Several people ran to help her when she fell.
run.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: Firefighters are to run 500km to raise money for a children’s charity.
He ran the length of the corridor.
run.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: I’d never run a marathon before.
Murray has said she will consider running in the 3000 metres.
run.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: if a race is run at a particular time or in a particular place, it happens at that time or in that place
run.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: The Derby will be run at 3 o'clock.
run.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to organize or be in charge of an activity, business, organization, or country
run.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: For a while, she ran a restaurant in Boston.
Many people don’t care who runs the country.
Courses are currently being run in London and Edinburgh.
Many people belong to a pension scheme run by their employers.
a state-run (=controlled by the government) television station
The hotel is well-run and extremely popular.
run.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to do something or go somewhere quickly
run.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: Run and ask your mother where she’s put the keys.
I need to run to the store for some more milk.
run.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: if a bus, train etc service runs, it takes people from one place to another at fixed times
run.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: The buses don’t run on Sundays.
The number 61 bus runs to the city centre.
run.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: if a company or other organization runs a bus, train etc service, they make it operate
run.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: They’re running special trains to and from the exhibition.
run.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: if a computer program runs, it operates
run.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: The software will run on any PC.
run.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: if you run a program, you make it operate
run.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: The RS8 system runs both Unix and MPX-32.
run.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: if a machine or engine runs, it operates
run.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: She got out of the car and left the engine running.
Most cars run on unleaded fuel.
run.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: if you run a machine or engine, you make it operate
run.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: You shouldn’t keep the engine running when the car is standing still.
I often run the washing machine more than once a day.
run.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: if a tape is running, it is recording
run.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: She didn’t realize the tape was running as she spoke.
run.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: if you run a tape, you make it move backwards or forwards
run.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: Run the tape back to the beginning.
run.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: to print something in a newspaper or magazine, or broadcast something on television
run.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: The company is running a series of advertisements in national newspapers.
A local TV station ran her story.
run.translation[0].definitions[15].defin: if a program runs on television, it is shown. If a story runs in a newspaper or magazine, it is printed
run.translation[0].definitions[15].examp: The series ran for 20 episodes and was extremely popular.
Conan Doyle’s stories ran in ‘The Strand’ magazine.
run.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: to move too fast or in an uncontrolled way
run.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: Her car ran off the road and into a tree.
The truck ran out of control and hit a house.
run.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: to own and use a vehicle
run.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: I can’t afford to run a car.
A bicycle is relatively cheap to buy and run.
run.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: to take someone somewhere in your car
run.translation[0].definitions[18].examp: Let me run you to the station.
run.translation[0].definitions[19].defin: to try to be elected in an election
run.translation[0].definitions[19].examp: Salinas is running for a second term as president.
an attempt to encourage more women to run for office
Feinstein will win if she runs against Lungren.
run.translation[0].definitions[20].defin: if something long such as a road or wire runs in a particular direction, that is its position, or that is where you put it
run.translation[0].definitions[20].examp: The road runs along a valley.
Developers want to run a road right through his farm.
Run the cables under the carpet.
The Sierra mountain range runs the length of the north west coast of Majorca.
run.translation[0].definitions[21].defin: to move something lightly along a surface
run.translation[0].definitions[21].examp: Charles ran his fingers through her hair.
Run the scanner over the bar codes.
run.translation[0].definitions[22].defin: to flow in a particular direction or place
run.translation[0].definitions[22].examp: Tears started to run down her cheeks.
Water was running off the roof.
run.translation[0].definitions[23].defin: if a tap is running, water is coming out of it, or if you run a tap, you make water come out of it
run.translation[0].definitions[23].examp: Did you leave the tap running?
He ran the tap until the water was really hot.
run.translation[0].definitions[24].defin: if someone’s nose is running, liquid is flowing out of it
run.translation[0].definitions[25].defin: if something runs for a particular length of time, it can officially be used for that time
run.translation[0].definitions[25].examp: The contract runs for a year.
My car insurance only has another month to run.
run.translation[0].definitions[26].defin: to continue being performed regularly in one place
run.translation[0].definitions[26].examp: The play ran for two years.
run.translation[0].definitions[27].defin: to happen in a particular way or at a particular time
run.translation[0].definitions[27].examp: Andy kept things running smoothly (=happening in the way they should) while I was away.
He was given a further three month prison sentence to run concurrently.
The course runs over a three year period.
run.translation[0].definitions[28].defin: to be at a particular level, amount, or price
run.translation[0].definitions[28].examp: The cost of repairing the damage could run to $5000.
run.translation[0].definitions[29].defin: if a story, discussion etc runs in a particular way, it has those particular words or events
run.translation[0].definitions[29].examp: The story runs that someone offered Lynch a further $500.
‘President’s marriage really over’ ran the headline in a national newspaper.
run.translation[0].definitions[30].defin: if a feeling runs through you, or a thought runs through your mind, you feel it or think it quickly
run.translation[0].definitions[30].examp: A feeling of excitement ran through her body as they touched.
The same thought kept running through his mind.
A cold shiver ran down my back.
I felt a sharp pain run down my leg.
run.translation[0].definitions[31].defin: if colour runs, it spreads from one piece of clothing or one area of cloth to another when the clothes are wet
run.translation[0].definitions[31].examp: The T-shirt ran and made all my other clothes pink.
run.translation[0].definitions[32].defin: if paint runs, it moves onto an area where you did not intend it to go
run.translation[0].definitions[33].defin: if a hole in tights or stockings runs, it gets bigger in a straight line
run.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: to move very quickly, by moving your legs more quickly than when you walk
My five-year-old son runs everywhere.
I go running twice a week.
jog
to run quite slowly for exercise over a long distance
A few people were jogging in the park.
race/dash
to run somewhere as quickly as you can, especially because you have to do something urgently
He dashed across the road to the police station.
We raced to the bus stop and got there just in time.
sprint
to run as fast as you can for a short distance
I saw the runners sprinting past.
He sprinted up the stairs.
tear
to run very quickly and without really looking where you are going, because you are in a hurry
He tore down the street and around the corner.
charge
to run quickly and with a lot of energy, so that you might knock down anyone or anything that gets in your way
They all charged out of the school gates at 4 o'clock.
Dennis charged through the door into my office.
take to your heels
to start running away very quickly, especially to escape or because you are afraid
The men took to their heels as soon as they saw the police.
leg it
to run away very quickly, in order to escape from someone or something
I legged it before the cops came.
lope
to run easily with long steps – used especially about tall people with long legs
John loped across the street to meet me.
animals running
trot
to run fairly slowly, taking short steps – used especially about horses and dogs
A little dog was trotting behind her.
gallop
if a horse gallops, it runs very quickly
The horse galloped off across the field.
bolt
to suddenly run somewhere very fast, especially in order to escape
Suddenly a fox bolted out from beneath a hedge.
run.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: a period of time spent running, or a distance that you run
run.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: She usually goes for a run before breakfast.
He was still following me, and in a panic I broke into a run.
Sarah left the house at a run.
run.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: a series of successes or failures
run.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: Losing my job was the start of a run of bad luck that year.
His extraordinary run of successes has been stopped.
run.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: an amount of a product produced at one time
run.translation[1].definitions[3].defini: a continuous series of performances of a play, film etc in the same place
run.translation[1].definitions[3].exampl: His first play had a three-month run in the West End.
run.translation[1].definitions[4].defini: a journey by train, ship, truck etc made regularly between two places
run.translation[1].definitions[4].exampl: It’s only a 55-minute run from London to Brighton.
the daily school run (=the journey that parents make each day taking their children to and from school) British English
run.translation[1].definitions[5].defini: a short journey in a car, for pleasure
run.translation[1].definitions[5].exampl: Let’s take the car out for a run.
run.translation[1].definitions[6].defini: an enclosed area where animals such as chickens or rabbits are kept
run.translation[1].definitions[7].defini: a point won in cricket or baseball
run.translation[1].definitions[8].defini: a special area or track on a mountain for people to ski or sledge down
run.translation[1].definitions[9].defini: an attempt to be elected to an important position
run.translation[1].definitions[9].exampl: He is preparing a run for the presidency.
run.translation[1].definitions[10].defin: a line of torn stitches in tights or stockings
run.translation[1].definitions[11].defin: a set of notes played or sung quickly up or down a scale in a piece of music
run.translation[1].definitions[12].defin: a set of cards with numbers in a series, held by one player
run.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to control or be in charge of an organization, company, or system
run.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: I’ve always wanted to run my own business.
For a while, she ran a restaurant in Boston.
A well-run company should not have problems of this kind.
run.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: if you run a machine or a computer program, you make it work
run.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: How many times a week do you run your washing machine?
The software will run on any PC.
cars that run on unleaded petrol
run.translation[2].definitions[2].exampl: The new system won’t be up and running until next week.
run.translation[2].definitions[3].defini: to continue to be VALID (legally or officially acceptable) for a particular period of time
run.translation[2].definitions[3].exampl: The contract runs for a year.
My car insurance only has another year to run.
run.translation[2].definitions[4].defini: to happen or take place, especially in the way that was intended
run.translation[2].definitions[4].exampl: So far, it had all run according to plan (=happened in the way that had been planned).
Her job is to ensure university catering runs smoothly (=happens with no unexpected problems).
run.translation[2].definitions[5].defini: to operate a bus, train, or plane service
run.translation[2].definitions[5].exampl: They’re running special trains to and from the exhibition.
run.translation[2].definitions[6].defini: to currently be at a particular level
run.translation[2].definitions[6].exampl: Inflation at that time was running at 10%.
run.translation[2].definitions[7].defini: to have very little of something left
run.translation[2].definitions[7].exampl: The insurance fund was running short of cash.
run.translation[2].definitions[8].defini: to be doing everything later than planned or expected
run.translation[2].definitions[8].exampl: They were running late, so I didn’t get interviewed until nearly 4 o'clock.
run.translation[2].definitions[9].defini: to check or test someone or something
run.translation[2].definitions[9].exampl: Car-rental companies are running background checks on drivers who rent for long periods.
She worked for a company running credit checks on people.
run.translation[2].definitions[10].defin: to try to be elected in an election
run.translation[2].definitions[10].examp: He has yet to decide whether to run for chairman.
the candidates who are hoping to run against the President in November
run.translation[2].definitions[11].defin: to print an advertisement, a story etc in a newspaper or magazine
run.translation[2].definitions[11].examp: magazines that don’t run tobacco ads
The paper still runs articles that anger dealers.
run.translation[2].definitions[12].defin: to have less or more money than is needed
run.translation[2].definitions[12].examp: The government is running a large budget surplus.
run.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: a series of similar events, especially successes or failures
run.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: The company has had a run of spectacularly successful years.
run.translation[3].definitions[1].defini: when a lot of people suddenly buy a particular product
run.translation[3].definitions[1].exampl: Controls were necessary to prevent a run on inexpensive Czech goods.
run.translation[3].definitions[2].defini: when a lot of people all take their money out of a bank at the same time
run.translation[3].definitions[2].exampl: A run on any bank could spread to other banks and threaten the entire system.
Even a minor bank run could bring down the system.
run.translation[3].definitions[3].defini: when a lot of people sell dollars, pounds etc and their value goes down
run.translation[3].definitions[3].exampl: Financial markets panicked, causing a run on the Brazilian currency.
run.translation[3].definitions[4].defini: at a later time in the future or over a longer period of time
run.translation[3].definitions[4].exampl: The company believes that the move will save it money in the long run.
run.translation[3].definitions[5].exampl: The plan does provide some help in the short run.
run.translation[3].definitions[6].defini: an amount of a product that is produced at one time
run.translation[3].definitions[6].exampl: Large production runs are necessary in order to cover the massive fixed costs involved in developing new cars.
The book has already sold out its initial print run of 20,000 copies.
run.translation[3].definitions[7].defini: run of book etc advertisements can be put anywhere in a magazine or newspaper, or on any website or part of a website, rather than in a particular place
